Flow Matching

Reference

Flow Matching For Generative Modeling

Continuous Normalizing Flows

Flow Straight and Fast

Preliminaries

The objective of generative modeling is to learn the underlying distribution pdata(x)p_{data}(x)pdata​(x) of the training data xxx. This is typically achieved by training a generative model pmodel(x)p_{model}(x)pmodel​(x) to approximate pdata(x)p_{data}(x)pdata​(x), allowing for the generation of new samples from the learned distribution.

Let XXX be a complete and separable metric space such as Ω⊆Rn\Omega \subseteq \mathbb R^nΩ⊆Rn. Then, the space of probability measures P(X)\mathcal{P}(X)P(X) is defined as the set of all Borel probability measures on XXX.

Generative models usually aims to learn a mapping from a simple distribution (e.g., Gaussian) to the complex data distribution pdata(x)p_{data}(x)pdata​(x) by transforming samples from the simple distribution into samples from the data distribution.

Topology on P(X)\mathcal P(X)P(X)

Weak Topology

the weak topology on P(X)P(X)P(X) is defined as the coarsest topology making all functionals of the form

μ↦∫Xf dμ\mu \mapsto \int_{X}f\,d\mu μ↦∫X​fdμ

continuous, where f∈Cb(X)f\in C_{b}(X)f∈Cb​(X) ranges over all the bounded continuous functions on XXX.

Convergence characterization: A sequence (μn)(\mu_n)(μn​)
converges to μ\muμ in the weak topology if and only if

∫Xf dμn→∫Xf dμ\int_X f \, d\mu_n \to \int_X f \, d\mu ∫X​fdμn​→∫X​fdμ

for all bounded continuous functions f:X→Rf: X \to \mathbb{R}f:X→R.

Actually, let M(X)\mathcal M(X)M(X) be the space of all signed, finite measure on XXX. Cb(X)C_b(X)Cb​(X) can be seen as the dual space induced by the pairing:

⟨f,μ⟩=∫Xf dμ\langle f,\mu \rangle = \int_{X}f\,d\mu ⟨f,μ⟩=∫X​fdμ

The relation between a measure on XXX and a linear functional (dual space) on Cb(X)C_b(X)Cb​(X):

Φ:M(X)→Cb(X)∗μ↦[f↦∫Xf dμ=⟨f,μ⟩]\begin{align*} \Phi:\mathcal{M}(X) &\to C_b(X)^*\\ \mu&\mapsto [f\mapsto \int_X f\, d\mu = \langle f, \mu \rangle] \end{align*} Φ:M(X)μ​→Cb​(X)∗↦[f↦∫X​fdμ=⟨f,μ⟩]​

Φ\PhiΦ is linear and injective.

When XXX is compact, Φ\PhiΦ is bijective by the Riesz representation theorem. M(X)≅Cb(X)∗\mathcal{M}(X)\cong C_b(X)^*M(X)≅Cb​(X)∗.

When XXX is locally compact and separable, M(X)≅C0(X)∗\mathcal{M}(X)\cong C_0(X)^*M(X)≅C0​(X)∗, where C0(X)C_0(X)C0​(X) is the compactly support function on XXX, which vanishing on infinity.

And we have the weak* topology on the dual space of Cb(X)C_b(X)Cb​(X)

Ln→w∗L  ⟺  Ln(f)→L(f),∀f∈Cb(X)L_n\overset{w^*}{\to} L \iff L_n(f)\to L(f),\quad \forall f\in C_b(X) Ln​→w∗L⟺Ln​(f)→L(f),∀f∈Cb​(X)

So Φ\PhiΦ induces the weak* topology on M(X)\mathcal M(X)M(X) and its subset P(X)P(X)P(X).

Wasserstein Metric Topology

When XXX is a compact Riemann manifold (M,g)(M,g)(M,g), the ppp-Wasserstein distance is a metric on P(X)\mathcal{P}(X)P(X), and induced a topology on MMM. More precisely, for probability distribution with finite ppp-th moment, Pp(X)\mathcal{P}_p(X)Pp​(X).

Kantorovich-Rubinstein duality states that for any ppp-Wasserstein distance, we have:

W1(μ,ν)=sup⁡f∈Lip1(M)(∫Mf dμ−∫Mf dν)W_1(\mu, \nu) = \sup_{f \in \text{Lip}_1(M)} \left( \int_M f \, d\mu - \int_M f \, d\nu \right) W1​(μ,ν)=f∈Lip1​(M)sup​(∫M​fdμ−∫M​fdν)

where W1(μ,ν)W_1(\mu, \nu)W1​(μ,ν) is the 111-Wasserstein distance.

This plays an important role in WGAN.

So 111-Wasserstein convergence is equivalent to convergence over all Lipschitz functions fff, which is stronger than weak convergence (all CbC_bCb​ functions).

Generally, we have

Wn(μ,ν)≤Wm(μ,ν),∀n≤mW_n(\mu, \nu)\leq W_m(\mu, \nu),\forall n\leq m Wn​(μ,ν)≤Wm​(μ,ν),∀n≤m

So 222-Wasserstein topology is weaker than 111-Wasserstein metric topology, etc.

But if we assume all the probability measure has compact support, the convergence is equivalent.

Let μ∈P(X)\mu \in \mathcal{P}(X)μ∈P(X) be the simple distribution, e.g. μ=N(0,I)\mu=\mathcal{N}(0, I)μ=N(0,I), and let ν∈P(X)\nu \in \mathcal{P}(X)ν∈P(X) be the data distribution. The goal is to learn a mapping f:X→Xf: X \to Xf:X→X such that f∗μ=νf_{*}\mu = \nuf∗​μ=ν, where f∗μf_{*}\muf∗​μ is the pushforward measure of μ\muμ under the mapping fff defined by f∗μ(A):=μ(f−1(A))f_{*}\mu(A) := \mu(f^{-1}(A))f∗​μ(A):=μ(f−1(A)), where A∈BXA\in \mathcal{B}_XA∈BX​ is a Borel set.

f∗:P(X)→P(X)μ↦f∗μ=ν\begin{align*} f_{*}: \mathcal{P}(X) &\to \mathcal{P}(X) \\ \mu &\mapsto f_{*}\mu = \nu \end{align*} f∗​:P(X)μ​→P(X)↦f∗​μ=ν​

But in reality, we only have the samples from the data distribution ν\nuν. So the best we can do is to approximate ν\nuν by

ν≈1N∑i=1Nδxi\nu \approx \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N} \delta_{x_i} ν≈N1​i=1∑N​δxi​​

where xi∈Xx_i\in Xxi​∈X is the sample data and δxi\delta_{x_i}δxi​​ is the Dirac measure centered at xix_ixi​.

This can be viewed as a semi-discrete optimal transport problem, where we aim to find a mapping f:X→Xf: X \to Xf:X→X that pushes forward the simple distribution μ\muμ to the empirical distribution ν\nuν.

Data Manifold Hypothesis

We view the real distribution as a distribution over M\mathcal{M}M, where M\mathcal{M}M is a manifold embedded in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn and nnn is the dimensionality of the data. More precisely, we assume that the data distribution ν\nuν has support on a lower-dimensional manifold M⊂Rn\mathcal{M} \subset \mathbb{R}^nM⊂Rn, typically with dim⁡(M)≪n\dim(\mathcal{M}) \ll ndim(M)≪n. This is the data manifold hypothesis, which posits that high-dimensional data often lies on or near a lower-dimensional manifold.

Theoretical Framework vs. Practical Implementation

Theoretical assumption:

The true data distribution pdata(x)p_{data}(x)pdata​(x) is absolutely continuous with respect to the volume measure on the data manifold M\mathcal{M}M, i.e., there exists a smooth density function ρdata:M→R+\rho_{data}: \mathcal{M} \to \mathbb{R}_+ρdata​:M→R+​ such that:

dν=ρdata(x) dvolM(x)d\nu = \rho_{data}(x) \, d\text{vol}_\mathcal{M}(x) dν=ρdata​(x)dvolM​(x)

Practical reality:

We only observe finite samples {xi}i=1N\{x_i\}_{i=1}^N{xi​}i=1N​ from the true distribution, leading to the empirical distribution:

ν^N=1N∑i=1Nδxi\hat{\nu}_N = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N} \delta_{x_i} ν^N​=N1​i=1∑N​δxi​​

Note that each Dirac measure δxi\delta_{x_i}δxi​​ is not absolutely continuous with respect to the volume measure, since {xi}\{x_i\}{xi​} has zero volume but δxi({xi})=1\delta_{x_i}(\{x_i\}) = 1δxi​​({xi​})=1.

Regularization assumption: We assume that the empirical distribution ν^N\hat{\nu}_Nν^N​ converges weakly to the true continuous distribution ν\nuν as N→∞N \to \inftyN→∞:

ν^N⇀νas N→∞\hat{\nu}_N \rightharpoonup \nu \quad \text{as } N \to \infty ν^N​⇀νas N→∞

This weak convergence justifies treating the discrete empirical distribution as an approximation to the underlying continuous distribution.

But we can instead use a Gaussian kernel to smooth the empirical distribution:

ν~N=1N∑i=1NKσ(x−xi)δxi\tilde{\nu}_N = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N} K_\sigma(x - x_i) \delta_{x_i} ν~N​=N1​i=1∑N​Kσ​(x−xi​)δxi​​

where Kσ(x)K_\sigma(x)Kσ​(x) is a Gaussian kernel with bandwidth σ\sigmaσ.

We shall see this is the choice of the flow matching.

(Discrete) Normalizing Flow

We learn a bijective mapping f:Rn→Rnf: \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^nf:Rn→Rn such that the pushforward measure f∗μf_{*}\muf∗​μ matches the target distribution ν\nuν.

The Normalizing Flow method assumes that fff can be expressed as a sequence of invertible transformations, typically using neural networks, such that the Jacobian determinant can be efficiently computed.

y∼ν,y=f(x),x∼μ=N(0,I)y \sim \nu, y = f(x), x \sim \mu= \mathcal{N}(0, I) y∼ν,y=f(x),x∼μ=N(0,I)

f=fn⋯∘f1x1=f1(x)x2=f2(x1)⋮y=xn=fn(xn−1)\begin{align*} f &= f_n \cdots \circ f_1\\ x_1 &= f_1(x) \\ x_2 &= f_2(x_1) \\ \vdots \\ y = x_n &= f_n(x_{n-1}) \end{align*} fx1​x2​⋮y=xn​​=fn​⋯∘f1​=f1​(x)=f2​(x1​)=fn​(xn−1​)​

And each fif_ifi​ is a neural network parameterized by θi\theta_iθi​, i.e., fi=fi(x;θi)f_i = f_i(x; \theta_i)fi​=fi​(x;θi​).

Loss and Training

The objective is maximum likelihood estimation or KL divergence, equivalently.

By the change of variables formula, we have:

pY(y)=pX(f−1(y))∣det⁡∂f−1∂y∣p_Y(y) = p_X(f^{-1}(y)) \left| \det \frac{\partial f^{-1}}{\partial y} \right| pY​(y)=pX​(f−1(y))​det∂y∂f−1​​

L(θ)=1N∑i=1Nlog⁡pY(yi)=1N∑i=1Nlog⁡pX(f−1(yi))∣det⁡∂f−1∂yi∣\begin{align*} \mathcal L(\theta) &= \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N \log p_Y(y_i) \\ &= \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N \log p_X(f^{-1}(y_i)) \left| \det \frac{\partial f^{-1}}{\partial y_i} \right|\\ \end{align*} L(θ)​=N1​i=1∑N​logpY​(yi​)=N1​i=1∑N​logpX​(f−1(yi​))​det∂yi​∂f−1​​​

Continuous Normalizing Flows

Let n→∞n\to \inftyn→∞, it is equivalent to construct a vector field (and corresponding ODE) and take the transform process as particle flows.

Given a time dependent transformation

g:[0,1]×Ω→Ω(t,x)↦g(t,x)\begin{align*} g: [0,1] \times \mathbb \Omega &\to \mathbb \Omega\\ (t,x) &\mapsto g(t,x) \end{align*} g:[0,1]×Ω(t,x)​→Ω↦g(t,x)​

The flow ggg induces a time-dependent one parameter group of diffeomorphisms:

gt(x)=g(t,x)g_t(x) = g(t,x) gt​(x)=g(t,x)

And the trajectory of a particle xxx is denoted as γx(t)\gamma_x(t)γx​(t):

γx(t)=g(t,x)=gt(x)\gamma_x(t) = g(t,x) = g_t(x) γx​(t)=g(t,x)=gt​(x)

Note that here particle xxx means it was initially at position xxx at time t=0t=0t=0.

We want a gradual transformation of the input distribution to the target distribution, i.e.

g0=id,g1=Tg_0 = \text{id}, g_1 = T g0​=id,g1​=T

And TTT satisfies T∗μ=νT_* \mu = \nuT∗​μ=ν.

Fix a position yyy and describe the speed of the particles at yyy, we can define the velocity field vt(y)v_t(y)vt​(y) as:

vt(y)=∂∂tg(t,x)∣g(t,x)=y=∂g∂t(t,gt−1(y))v_t(y) = \frac{\partial}{\partial t} g(t, x)\bigg|_{g(t,x)=y} = \frac{\partial g}{\partial t}(t, g_t^{-1}(y)) vt​(y)=∂t∂​g(t,x)​g(t,x)=y​=∂t∂g​(t,gt−1​(y))

And the Eulerian description and Lagrangian description are related as follows:
Eulerian:

{ddtgt(x)=vt(gt(x)),g0(x)=x.\begin{cases} \frac{d}{dt}g_t(x) = v_t(g_t(x)),\\ g_0(x)=x. \end{cases} {dtd​gt​(x)=vt​(gt​(x)),g0​(x)=x.​

Lagrangian:

{ddtγx(t)=vt(γx(t)),γx(0)=x.\begin{cases} \frac{d}{dt}\gamma_x(t) = v_t(\gamma_x(t)),\\ \gamma_x(0)=x. \end{cases} {dtd​γx​(t)=vt​(γx​(t)),γx​(0)=x.​

We shall now consider the conservation of mass, i.e., we want to ensure that the flow preserves the total mass 111 of the distribution.

We thus introduce a density function ρ\rhoρ induced by the flow

ρ(t,x):[0,1]×Ω→R(t,x)↦ρ(t,x)\begin{align*} \rho(t,x): [0,1] \times \Omega &\to \mathbb{R}\\ (t,x) &\mapsto \rho(t,x) \end{align*} ρ(t,x):[0,1]×Ω(t,x)​→R↦ρ(t,x)​

And denote ρt(x):Ω→R\rho_t(x):\Omega \to \mathbb {R}ρt​(x):Ω→R as ρ(t,x)\rho(t,x)ρ(t,x).

We require

ρt=(gt)∗ρ0\rho_t = (g_t)_*\rho_0 ρt​=(gt​)∗​ρ0​

Particularly, ρ0=μ,ρ1=ν\rho_0 = \mu, \rho_1 = \nuρ0​=μ,ρ1​=ν.

And we assume vvv is tangent to the boundary ∂Ω\partial \Omega∂Ω, and the flow remains inside of Ω\OmegaΩ, thus ρt∈P(Ω)\rho_t \in \mathcal{P}(\Omega)ρt​∈P(Ω).

It must satisfy the continuity equation to make the probability mass conserve

∂tρt+∇⋅(vtρt)=0\partial_t \rho_t + \nabla \cdot (v_t \rho_t) = 0 ∂t​ρt​+∇⋅(vt​ρt​)=0

Proof of continuity equation

Let ϕ∈Cb(Ω)\phi\in C_b(\Omega)ϕ∈Cb​(Ω),

∫Ω∂tϕρt dΩ=∫Ω∂tϕ dρt=ddt∫Ωϕ(x) d((gt)∗ρ0)=ddt∫Ωϕ(gt) dρ0=∫Ω∇ϕ(gt)⋅vt(gt) dρ0=∫Ω∇ϕ⋅vt dρt=−∫Ωϕ(∇⋅vtρt)dΩ\begin{align*} \int_{\Omega} \partial_t \phi\rho_t\, d\Omega &=\int_{\Omega} \partial_t \phi\, d\rho_t\\ &= \frac{d}{dt} \int_{\Omega} \phi(x) \, d((g_t)_* \rho_0) \\ &= \frac{d}{dt} \int_{\Omega} \phi(g_t)\, d\rho_0 \\ &= \int_{\Omega} \nabla \phi(g_t) \cdot v_t(g_t) \, d\rho_0 \\ &= \int_{\Omega} \nabla \phi \cdot v_t \, d\rho_t\\ &= -\int_{\Omega} \phi \left(\nabla\cdot v_t\rho_t \right) d\Omega \end{align*} ∫Ω​∂t​ϕρt​dΩ​=∫Ω​∂t​ϕdρt​=dtd​∫Ω​ϕ(x)d((gt​)∗​ρ0​)=dtd​∫Ω​ϕ(gt​)dρ0​=∫Ω​∇ϕ(gt​)⋅vt​(gt​)dρ0​=∫Ω​∇ϕ⋅vt​dρt​=−∫Ω​ϕ(∇⋅vt​ρt​)dΩ​

By the arbitrariness of ϕ\phiϕ, we get the continuity equation:

∂tρt+∇⋅(vtρt)=0\partial_t \rho_t + \nabla \cdot (v_t \rho_t) = 0 ∂t​ρt​+∇⋅(vt​ρt​)=0

We say the (ρt,vt)(\rho_t,v_t)(ρt​,vt​) solve the continuity in distributional sense, which is called a weak solution or distributional solution.

From the Lagrangian description, we know the formula:

Jt=∣det⁡∂gt∂x∣=∣det⁡Ft∣J_t = \left |\det \frac{\partial g_t}{\partial x} \right | = \left | \det F_t \right| Jt​=​det∂x∂gt​​​=∣detFt​∣

ρt(gt)⋅Jt=ρ0\rho_t(g_t)\cdot J_t = \rho_0 ρt​(gt​)⋅Jt​=ρ0​

Take differential on both side,

Jtdρt(gt)+ρt(gt)dJt=0J_td \rho_t(g_t) + \rho_t(g_t) dJ_t = 0 Jt​dρt​(gt​)+ρt​(gt​)dJt​=0

And

dJtdt=Jt⋅tr⁡(Ft−1dFtdt)\frac{d J_t}{dt}=J_t\cdot \operatorname{tr}\left(F_t^{-1} \frac{dF_t}{dt}\right) dtdJt​​=Jt​⋅tr(Ft−1​dtdFt​​)

dFtdt=∂∂t∂gt∂x=ddx∂gt∂t=ddxvt(gt)=∇vt(gt)⋅Ft\frac{d F_t}{d t} = \frac{\partial}{\partial t}\frac{\partial g_t}{\partial x} = \frac{d}{d x} \frac{\partial g_t}{\partial t} = \frac{d}{dx} v_t(g_t) = \nabla v_t(g_t) \cdot F_t dtdFt​​=∂t∂​∂x∂gt​​=dxd​∂t∂gt​​=dxd​vt​(gt​)=∇vt​(gt​)⋅Ft​

Hence

dJtdt=Jt⋅tr⁡(∇vt(gt))=Jt⋅(∇⋅vt(gt))\frac{d J_t}{d t}= J_t \cdot \operatorname{tr}\left(\nabla v_t(g_t)\right) = J_t \cdot( \nabla \cdot v_t(g_t)) dtdJt​​=Jt​⋅tr(∇vt​(gt​))=Jt​⋅(∇⋅vt​(gt​))

Take it back, and eliminate JtJ_tJt​

dρt(gt)+ρt(gt)(∇⋅vt(gt))=0d\rho_t(g_t) + \rho_t(g_t) (\nabla \cdot v_t(g_t)) = 0 dρt​(gt​)+ρt​(gt​)(∇⋅vt​(gt​))=0

And dρt(gt)=∂ρt∂t(gt)+∇ρt(gt)⋅vt(gt)d\rho_t(g_t) = \frac{\partial \rho_t}{\partial t}(g_t) + \nabla \rho_t(g_t) \cdot v_t(g_t)dρt​(gt​)=∂t∂ρt​​(gt​)+∇ρt​(gt​)⋅vt​(gt​).

∂ρt∂t(gt)+∇ρt(gt)⋅vt(gt)+ρt(gt)(∇⋅vt(gt))=0\frac{\partial \rho_t}{\partial t}(g_t) + \nabla \rho_t(g_t) \cdot v_t(g_t) + \rho_t(g_t) (\nabla \cdot v_t(g_t)) = 0 ∂t∂ρt​​(gt​)+∇ρt​(gt​)⋅vt​(gt​)+ρt​(gt​)(∇⋅vt​(gt​))=0

∂ρt∂t(gt)+∇⋅(vt(gt)ρt(gt))=0\frac{\partial \rho_t}{\partial t}(g_t) + \nabla \cdot (v_t(g_t) \rho_t(g_t)) = 0 ∂t∂ρt​​(gt​)+∇⋅(vt​(gt​)ρt​(gt​))=0

since gtg_tgt​ is a diffeomorphism, we have:

∂ρt∂t+∇⋅(vtρt)=0\frac{\partial \rho_t}{\partial t} + \nabla \cdot (v_t \rho_t) = 0 ∂t∂ρt​​+∇⋅(vt​ρt​)=0

Note: If we further assume the incompressibility condition, i.e.

∂ρt∂t=0\frac{\partial \rho_t}{\partial t} = 0 ∂t∂ρt​​=0

then we have

∇⋅vt=0\nabla \cdot v_t = 0 ∇⋅vt​=0

So we know

∂ρt∂t(x)=−∇⋅(vt(x)⋅ρt(x))\frac{\partial \rho_t}{\partial t} (x)= -\nabla \cdot (v_t(x) \cdot \rho_t(x)) ∂t∂ρt​​(x)=−∇⋅(vt​(x)⋅ρt​(x))

Now we focus on a particle is initially at xxx, moving on trajectory xt=γx(t)x_t=\gamma_x(t)xt​=γx​(t)

ddtρt(γx(t))=∂ρt∂t(γx(t))+∇ρt(γx(t))⋅ddtγx(t)=∂ρt∂t(γx(t))+∇ρt(γx(t))⋅vt(γx(t))=−∇⋅(vtρt)(γx(t))+∇ρt(γx(t))⋅vt(γx(t))=−ρt(γx(t))∇⋅vt(γx(t))\begin{align*} \frac{d}{dt} \rho_t(\gamma_x(t)) &= \frac{\partial \rho_t}{\partial t}(\gamma_x(t)) + \nabla \rho_t(\gamma_x(t)) \cdot \frac{d}{dt} \gamma_x(t) \\ &= \frac{\partial \rho_t}{\partial t}(\gamma_x(t)) + \nabla \rho_t(\gamma_x(t)) \cdot v_t(\gamma_x(t)) \\ &= -\nabla \cdot (v_t\rho_t)(\gamma_x(t)) + \nabla \rho_t(\gamma_x(t)) \cdot v_t(\gamma_x(t))\\ &= -\rho_t(\gamma_x(t))\nabla \cdot v_t(\gamma_x(t)) \end{align*} dtd​ρt​(γx​(t))​=∂t∂ρt​​(γx​(t))+∇ρt​(γx​(t))⋅dtd​γx​(t)=∂t∂ρt​​(γx​(t))+∇ρt​(γx​(t))⋅vt​(γx​(t))=−∇⋅(vt​ρt​)(γx​(t))+∇ρt​(γx​(t))⋅vt​(γx​(t))=−ρt​(γx​(t))∇⋅vt​(γx​(t))​

So

ddtlog⁡ρt(γx(t))=1ρt(γx(t))ddtρt(γx(t))=−∇⋅vt(γx(t))\frac{d}{dt}\log \rho_t(\gamma_x(t)) = \frac{1}{\rho_t(\gamma_x(t))} \frac{d}{dt} \rho_t(\gamma_x(t)) = - \nabla \cdot v_t(\gamma_x(t)) dtd​logρt​(γx​(t))=ρt​(γx​(t))1​dtd​ρt​(γx​(t))=−∇⋅vt​(γx​(t))

Thus

log⁡ρ1(x1)−log⁡ρ0(x0)=−∫01∇⋅vt(xt)dt\log \rho_{1}(x_1) - \log \rho_{0}(x_0)= -\int_0^1 \nabla \cdot v_t(x_t) dt logρ1​(x1​)−logρ0​(x0​)=−∫01​∇⋅vt​(xt​)dt

Loss and Training

We simulate the flow by using a neural network gθg_\thetagθ​ with parameter θ\thetaθ.

Similar to the discrete normalizing flow, we use MLE:

L(θ)=−Ex1∼ν[log⁡ρ1,θ(x1)]=−Ex1∼ν[log⁡μ(x0)−∫01∇⋅vt,θ(xt)]\begin{align*} \mathcal L(\theta)&= -\mathbb{E}_{x_1\sim \nu}\left[\log \rho_{1,\theta}(x_1)\right] \\ &= -\mathbb{E}_{x_1\sim\nu}\left[\log \mu(x_0)-\int_0^1 \nabla \cdot v_{t,\theta}(x_t)\right] \end{align*} L(θ)​=−Ex1​∼ν​[logρ1,θ​(x1​)]=−Ex1​∼ν​[logμ(x0​)−∫01​∇⋅vt,θ​(xt​)]​

Or equivalently, minimize the KL divergence between ρ1,θ\rho_{1,\theta}ρ1,θ​ and ν\nuν.

Flow Matching

Instead of learning ggg, flow matching directly learns the velocity field vt,θ(x)v_{t,\theta}(x)vt,θ​(x).

The theoretical objective is:

LFM=Et∼U[0,1],xt∼ρt∥vt,θ(xt)−vt(xt)∥2\mathcal{L}_{FM}=\mathbb E_{t\sim\mathcal{U}[0,1],x_t\sim \rho_t} \|v_{t,\theta}(x_t)-v_t(x_t)\|^2 LFM​=Et∼U[0,1],xt​∼ρt​​∥vt,θ​(xt​)−vt​(xt​)∥2

But this cannot be trained directly since we don’t know vtv_tvt​.

Conditional Flow Matching

conditioning on x1x_1x1​, CFM use the conditional distribution ρt(xt∣x1)\rho_t(x_t|x_1)ρt​(xt​∣x1​)

Key theorem:

Given conditional probability path ρt(xt∣x1)\rho_t(x_t|x_1)ρt​(xt​∣x1​) satisfying the continuity equation with conditional vector field vt(xt∣x1)v_t(x_t| x_1)vt​(xt​∣x1​).

Then the marginal vector field vtv_tvt​:

vt(x)=∫vt(xt∣x1)ρt(xt∣x1)ν(x1)ρt(x)dx1v_t(x)=\int v_t(x_t|x_1) \frac{\rho_t(x_t|x_1)\nu(x_1)}{\rho_t(x)} d{x_1} vt​(x)=∫vt​(xt​∣x1​)ρt​(x)ρt​(xt​∣x1​)ν(x1​)​dx1​

satisfy the continuity equation and generate the marginal probability path ρt(xt)\rho_t(x_t)ρt​(xt​).

And one can choose any conditional probability path as long as

ρ0(x∣x1)=μ,ρ1(x∣x1)=δ(x−x1)\rho_0(x|x_1) = \mu, \rho_1(x|x_1) = \delta(x-x_1) ρ0​(x∣x1​)=μ,ρ1​(x∣x1​)=δ(x−x1​)

And the paper use Gaussian kernal as an approximation.

If the above condition is satisfied, the paper proves that optimizing the objective of CFM is equivalent to optimizing the objective of the original flow model.

LCFM=Et∼U[0,1],x1∼ν,xt∼ρt(xt∣x1)[∥vt,θ(xt∣x1)−vt(xt∣x1)∥2]\mathcal L_{CFM} = \mathbb{E}_{t\sim\mathcal{U}[0,1],x_1\sim\nu,x_t\sim\rho_t(x_t|x_1)} \left[\|v_{t,\theta}(x_t|x_1) - v_t(x_t|x_1)\|^2\right] LCFM​=Et∼U[0,1],x1​∼ν,xt​∼ρt​(xt​∣x1​)​[∥vt,θ​(xt​∣x1​)−vt​(xt​∣x1​)∥2]

And ∇θLCFM=∇θLFM\nabla_{\theta} \mathcal L_{CFM}= \nabla_{\theta} \mathcal L_{FM}∇θ​LCFM​=∇θ​LFM​

And you can also condition on x0x_0x0​.

or both x0x_0x0​ and x1x_1x1​, the formula ∇θLCFM\nabla_{\theta} \mathcal L_{CFM}∇θ​LCFM​ is still valid if if the coupling π∈Γ(μ,ν)\pi\in \Gamma(\mu,\nu)π∈Γ(μ,ν) is fixed.

Rectified Flow

In the paper, rectified flow optimized the velocity field vtv_tvt​ by minimizing the following objective:

LRF=∫01E[∥(X1−X0)−v(Xt,t)∥2] dt, with  Xt=tX1+(1−t)X0\mathcal{L}_{RF}=\int_0^1 \mathbb{E} \left[\|(X_1-X_0)-v(X_t,t)\|^2 \right]\, \text{d}t,\, \text{with}\,\, X_t=tX_1+(1-t)X_0 LRF​=∫01​E[∥(X1​−X0​)−v(Xt​,t)∥2]dt,withXt​=tX1​+(1−t)X0​

where X0∼μ,X1∼νX_0\sim \mu, X_1\sim \nuX0​∼μ,X1​∼ν.

First, lets translate this into the CFM language.

Conditioning on x0x_0x0​ and x1x_1x1​, rectified flow defined a deterministic path as the interpolation between x0x_0x0​ and x1x_1x1​:

gt(x∣x0,x1)=tx1+(1−t)x0vt(x∣x0,x1)=∂tgt(x∣x0,x1)=x1−x0ρt(x∣x0,x1)=(gt(x∣x0,x1))∗ρ0(x∣x0,x1)=(gt(x∣x0,x1))∗δ(x−x0)=δ(gt−1(x∣x0,x1)−x0)∣det⁡∂gt−1∂x∣=δ(x−tx11−t−x0)1(1−t)n=δ(x−tx1−(1−t)x01−t)1(1−t)n=δ(x−tx1−(1−t)x0)(1−t)n1(1−t)n=δ(x−tx1−(1−t)x0)\begin{align*} g_t(x|x_0,x_1) &= t x_1 + (1-t)x_0\\ v_t(x|x_0,x_1) &= \partial_t g_t(x|x_0,x_1) = x_1 - x_0\\ \rho_t(x|x_0,x_1) &= (g_t(x|x_0,x_1))_* \rho_0(x|x_0,x_1)\\ &= (g_t(x|x_0,x_1))_* \delta(x - x_0) \\ &= \delta(g_t^{-1}(x|x_0,x_1) - x_0) \left| \det \frac{\partial g_t^{-1}}{\partial x} \right|\\ &= \delta(\frac{x-tx_1}{1-t} - x_0) \frac{1}{(1-t)^n}\\ &= \delta\left(\frac{x-tx_1-(1-t)x_0}{1-t}\right) \frac{1}{(1-t)^n}\\ &= \delta\left(x-tx_1-(1-t)x_0\right) (1-t)^{n} \frac{1}{(1-t)^n}\\ &= \delta\left(x-tx_1-(1-t)x_0\right)\\ \end{align*} gt​(x∣x0​,x1​)vt​(x∣x0​,x1​)ρt​(x∣x0​,x1​)​=tx1​+(1−t)x0​=∂t​gt​(x∣x0​,x1​)=x1​−x0​=(gt​(x∣x0​,x1​))∗​ρ0​(x∣x0​,x1​)=(gt​(x∣x0​,x1​))∗​δ(x−x0​)=δ(gt−1​(x∣x0​,x1​)−x0​)​det∂x∂gt−1​​​=δ(1−tx−tx1​​−x0​)(1−t)n1​=δ(1−tx−tx1​−(1−t)x0​​)(1−t)n1​=δ(x−tx1​−(1−t)x0​)(1−t)n(1−t)n1​=δ(x−tx1​−(1−t)x0​)​

And apply the CFM objective:

LRF=Et∼U[0,1],x0∼μ,x1∼ν,xt∼ρt(x∣x0,x1)[∥vt,θ(xt∣x0,x1)−vt(xt∣x0,x1)∥2]=∫01Ex0∼μ,x1∼ν,xt∼ρt(x∣x0,x1)[∥vt,θ(xt∣x0,x1)−(x1−x0)∥2] dt=∫01Ex0∼μ,x1∼ν[vt,θ(xt∣x0,x1)−(x1−x0)]2 dt\begin{align*} \mathcal{L}_{RF} &= \mathbb{E}_{t\sim\mathcal{U}[0,1],x_0\sim\mu,x_1\sim\nu,x_t\sim\rho_t(x|x_0,x_1)} \left[\|v_{t,\theta}(x_t|x_0,x_1) - v_t(x_t|x_0,x_1)\|^2\right]\\ &= \int_0^1 \mathbb{E}_{x_0\sim\mu,x_1\sim\nu,x_t\sim\rho_t(x|x_0,x_1)} \left[\|v_{t,\theta}(x_t|x_0,x_1) - (x_1-x_0)\|^2\right]\, \text{d}t\\ &= \int_0^1 \mathbb{E}_{x_0\sim\mu,x_1\sim\nu} \left[ v_{t,\theta}(x_t|x_0,x_1) - (x_1-x_0)\right]^2 \, \text{d}t\\ \end{align*} LRF​​=Et∼U[0,1],x0​∼μ,x1​∼ν,xt​∼ρt​(x∣x0​,x1​)​[∥vt,θ​(xt​∣x0​,x1​)−vt​(xt​∣x0​,x1​)∥2]=∫01​Ex0​∼μ,x1​∼ν,xt​∼ρt​(x∣x0​,x1​)​[∥vt,θ​(xt​∣x0​,x1​)−(x1​−x0​)∥2]dt=∫01​Ex0​∼μ,x1​∼ν​[vt,θ​(xt​∣x0​,x1​)−(x1​−x0​)]2dt​

And this is exactly the objective of rectified flow.

Actually, the author of Flow Matching For Generative Modeling also proposed an similar objective, but they use the name “OT-Flow” instead of “rectified flow” (And Gaussian kernal). We shall see the reason in the next section.

Relation to Optimal Transport

What does the rectified flow and conditional flow matching have to do with optimal transport? Let’s recall the method of conditional probability path.

The claim is that to get the vector field vtv_tvt​, we can use the conditional vector field ρt(xt∣x0,x1)\rho_t(x_t|x_0,x_1)ρt​(xt​∣x0​,x1​) and do summation over all x0x_0x0​ and x1x_1x1​. Then we shall get the vector field vtv_tvt​ that satisfies the continuity equation and generates the marginal probability path ρt(xt)\rho_t(x_t)ρt​(xt​).

It is not difficult to see that summing over the conditional vector field will yield a valid vector field that satisfies the continuity equation and transport the distribution from μ\muμ to ν\nuν. But what is the property of such vector field?

Let’s think about a principle in traditional physics, the principle of least action. It states that the path taken by a system between two states is the one for which the action is stationary (usually minimized).

In the context of traditional physics, the shortest path between two points is a straight line. But in quantum mechanics, the particle is no longer deterministic as a point, but rather a wave function that can be spread out over a region of space assigning a probability amplitude to each point. But the principle of least action still holds, and the path taken by the particle is the one that minimizes the action.

Benamou-Brenier Theory

The Benamou-Brenier theory states that the optimal transport problem can be reformulated as a dynamic problem, where the optimal transport plan is the one that minimizes the action functional.

In every time ttt, we have a distribution ρt\rho_tρt​ and a velocity field vtv_tvt​. The kinetic energy is given by the integral of the squared velocity field:

E(t)=∫Ω12∥vt(x)∥2ρt(x) dxE(t) = \int_{\Omega} \frac{1}{2}\|v_t(x)\|^2 \rho_t(x) \, dx E(t)=∫Ω​21​∥vt​(x)∥2ρt​(x)dx

The action functional is then defined as:

A(ρ,v)=∫01E(t) dt=∫01∫Ω12∥vt(x)∥2ρt(x) dx dtA(\rho, v) = \int_0^1 E(t) \, dt = \int_0^1 \int_{\Omega}\frac{1}{2}\|v_t(x)\|^2 \rho_t(x) \, dx \, dt A(ρ,v)=∫01​E(t)dt=∫01​∫Ω​21​∥vt​(x)∥2ρt​(x)dxdt

And we see the action functional is exactly the total energy of using the velocity field vtv_tvt​ to transport the distribution ρt\rho_tρt​ from μ\muμ to ν\nuν.

Problem (Benamou-Brenier): Given two probability measures μ\muμ and ν\nuν, find the optimal transport plan that minimizes the action functional A(ρ,v)A(\rho, v)A(ρ,v) subject to some conditions.

minA(ρ,v)s.t.(ρ,v)∈V(μ,ν)\begin{align*} \text{min} \quad & A(\rho, v) \\ \text{s.t.} \quad &(\rho,v)\in V(\mu,\nu) \end{align*} mins.t.​A(ρ,v)(ρ,v)∈V(μ,ν)​

Admissible pairs V(μ,ν)V(\mu,\nu)V(μ,ν) are pairs (ρ,v)(\rho, v)(ρ,v) such that:

  • ρ0=μ\rho_0 = \muρ0​=μ, ρ1=ν\rho_1 = \nuρ1​=ν,
  • ∂tρt+∇⋅(vtρt)=0\partial_t \rho_t + \nabla \cdot (v_t \rho_t) = 0∂t​ρt​+∇⋅(vt​ρt​)=0 in distributional sense,
  • ⋃t∈[0,1]supp(ρt)⊆Ω\bigcup_{t\in[0,1]} \text{supp}(\rho_t) \subseteq \Omega⋃t∈[0,1]​supp(ρt​)⊆Ω,
  • v∈L2(dρt(x)dt)v \in L^2(d\rho_t(x) dt)v∈L2(dρt​(x)dt), i.e., the velocity field is square integrable with respect to the measure ρt\rho_tρt​.
  • ρ∈C([0,1];w∗-Pac(Ω))\rho \in C([0,1]; w^*\text{-}P_{ac}(\mathbb \Omega))ρ∈C([0,1];w∗-Pac​(Ω)), i.e., the probability path is absolutely continuous with respect to the weak* topology on the space of probability measures.

Theorem: (Benamou-Brenier)

The 222-Wasserstein distance between two probability measures μ\muμ and ν\nuν can be expressed as the infimum of the action functional over all admissible pairs (ρ,v)(\rho, v)(ρ,v)

W22(μ,ν)=inf⁡(ρ,v)∈V(μ,ν)A(ρ,v)W_2^2 (\mu, \nu) = \inf_{(\rho, v) \in V(\mu, \nu)} A(\rho, v) W22​(μ,ν)=(ρ,v)∈V(μ,ν)inf​A(ρ,v)

This means that the optimal transport plan is the one that minimizes the action functional, which is equivalent to minimizing the total energy of the velocity field.

Variational Calculus

min⁡A(ρ,v)=∫01∫Ω12∥vt(x)∥2ρt(x) dx dts.t.∂tρt+∇⋅(vtρt)=0ρ0=μ,ρ1=ν\begin{align*} \min A(\rho, v) &= \int_0^1 \int_{\Omega} \frac{1}{2}\|v_t(x)\|^2 \rho_t(x) \, dx \, dt \\ \text{s.t.} \quad & \partial_t \rho_t + \nabla \cdot (v_t \rho_t) = 0 \\ & \rho_0 = \mu, \rho_1 = \nu \end{align*} minA(ρ,v)s.t.​=∫01​∫Ω​21​∥vt​(x)∥2ρt​(x)dxdt∂t​ρt​+∇⋅(vt​ρt​)=0ρ0​=μ,ρ1​=ν​

We introduce a Lagrange multiplier φt(x)\varphi_t(x)φt​(x) to enforce the continuity equation constraint:

J(ρ,v,ϕ)=∫01∫Ω[12∥vt(x)∥2ρt(x)+φt(x)(∂tρt(x)+∇⋅(vt(x)ρt(x)))] dx dt\begin{align*} \mathcal{J}(\rho, v, \phi) &=\int_0^1 \int_{\Omega} \left[\frac{1}{2}\|v_t(x)\|^2 \rho_t(x)+\varphi_t(x) \left( \partial_t \rho_t(x) + \nabla \cdot (v_t(x) \rho_t(x)) \right) \right] \,dx \, dt \end{align*} J(ρ,v,ϕ)​=∫01​∫Ω​[21​∥vt​(x)∥2ρt​(x)+φt​(x)(∂t​ρt​(x)+∇⋅(vt​(x)ρt​(x)))]dxdt​

Variation with respect to vvv:

δJδvt=∫01∫Ω[vt⋅δvtρt+φt∇⋅(δvtρt)] dx dt\frac{\delta \mathcal{J}}{\delta v_t} = \int_0^1 \int_{\Omega} \left[ v_t\cdot \delta v_t \rho_t + \varphi_t \nabla \cdot (\delta v_t \rho_t) \right] \, dx \, dt δvt​δJ​=∫01​∫Ω​[vt​⋅δvt​ρt​+φt​∇⋅(δvt​ρt​)]dxdt

Using integration by parts on the second term

∫Ωφt∇⋅(δvtρt) dx=∫Ω∇⋅(φtρtδvt) dx−∫Ω∇φt⋅(δvtρt) dx=∫∂Ωφtρtδvt⋅n dS−∫Ω∇φt⋅(δvtρt) dx=−∫Ω∇φt⋅(δvtρt) dx\begin{align*} \int_{\Omega} \varphi_t \nabla \cdot (\delta v_t \rho_t) \, dx &= \int_{\Omega} \nabla \cdot (\varphi_t \rho_t \delta v_t) \, dx - \int_{\Omega} \nabla \varphi_t \cdot (\delta v_t \rho_t) \, dx\\ &=\int_{\partial \Omega} \varphi_t \rho_t \delta v_t \cdot n \, dS - \int_{\Omega} \nabla \varphi_t \cdot (\delta v_t \rho_t) \, dx\\ &= - \int_{\Omega} \nabla \varphi_t \cdot (\delta v_t \rho_t) \, dx \end{align*} ∫Ω​φt​∇⋅(δvt​ρt​)dx​=∫Ω​∇⋅(φt​ρt​δvt​)dx−∫Ω​∇φt​⋅(δvt​ρt​)dx=∫∂Ω​φt​ρt​δvt​⋅ndS−∫Ω​∇φt​⋅(δvt​ρt​)dx=−∫Ω​∇φt​⋅(δvt​ρt​)dx​

where the boundary term vanishes due to the assumption that vvv is tangent to the boundary ∂Ω\partial \Omega∂Ω.

we get

δJδvt=∫01∫Ω[vtρt−ρt∇φt]⋅δvt dx dt\frac{\delta \mathcal{J}}{\delta v_t} = \int_0^1 \int_{\Omega} \left[ v_t\rho_t - \rho_t\nabla \varphi_t \right] \cdot \delta v_t \, dx \,dt δvt​δJ​=∫01​∫Ω​[vt​ρt​−ρt​∇φt​]⋅δvt​dxdt

Which forces

vt=∇φtv_t = \nabla \varphi_t vt​=∇φt​

Variation with respect to ρ\rhoρ:

δJδρt=∫01∫Ω[12∥vt(x)∥2+φt(x)∂tδρt(x)+φt(x)∇⋅(vt(x)δρt(x))] dx dt\frac{\delta \mathcal{J}}{\delta \rho_t} = \int_0^1 \int_{\Omega} \left[ \frac{1}{2}\|v_t(x)\|^2 + \varphi_t(x) \partial_t \delta \rho_t(x) + \varphi_t(x) \nabla \cdot (v_t(x) \delta \rho_t(x)) \right] \, dx \, dt δρt​δJ​=∫01​∫Ω​[21​∥vt​(x)∥2+φt​(x)∂t​δρt​(x)+φt​(x)∇⋅(vt​(x)δρt​(x))]dxdt

Similarly, using integration by parts on the second term and the third term

∫Ωφt∂tδρt dΩ=−∫Ω∂tφtδρt dΩ∫Ωφt∇⋅(vtδρt) dΩ=−∫Ω∇φt⋅(vtδρt) dΩ\begin{align*} \int_{\Omega} \varphi_t\partial_t\delta\rho_t \, d\Omega &= -\int_{\Omega} \partial_t\varphi_t\delta\rho_t\, d\Omega\\ \int_{\Omega} \varphi_t \nabla \cdot (v_t \delta \rho_t)\, d\Omega &= - \int_{\Omega} \nabla \varphi_t \cdot (v_t \delta \rho_t) \, d\Omega \end{align*} ∫Ω​φt​∂t​δρt​dΩ∫Ω​φt​∇⋅(vt​δρt​)dΩ​=−∫Ω​∂t​φt​δρt​dΩ=−∫Ω​∇φt​⋅(vt​δρt​)dΩ​

Note ρ0=μ\rho_0 = \muρ0​=μ and ρ1=ν\rho_1 = \nuρ1​=ν are fixed, so variations δρt\delta \rho_tδρt​ are zero at the endpoints (δρ0=δρ1=0)(\delta \rho_0 = \delta \rho_1 = 0)(δρ0​=δρ1​=0).

we get

δJδρt=∫01∫Ω[12∥vt(x)∥2−∂tφt(x)−∇φt(x)⋅vt(x)]δρt(x) dx dt\begin{align*} \frac{\delta \mathcal{J}}{\delta \rho_t} &= \int_0^1 \int_{\Omega} \left[ \frac{1}{2}\|v_t(x)\|^2 - \partial_t\varphi_t(x) - \nabla \varphi_t(x) \cdot v_t(x) \right] \delta\rho_t(x) \, dx \, dt \end{align*} δρt​δJ​​=∫01​∫Ω​[21​∥vt​(x)∥2−∂t​φt​(x)−∇φt​(x)⋅vt​(x)]δρt​(x)dxdt​

Setting this to zero for all δρt(x)\delta \rho_t(x)δρt​(x), we have

12∥vt(x)∥2−∂tφt(x)−∇φt(x)⋅vt(x)=0\frac{1}{2}\|v_t(x)\|^2 - \partial_t\varphi_t(x) - \nabla \varphi_t(x) \cdot v_t(x) = 0 21​∥vt​(x)∥2−∂t​φt​(x)−∇φt​(x)⋅vt​(x)=0

Substituting vt=∇φtv_t = \nabla \varphi_tvt​=∇φt​, we have

∂tφt(x)+12∥vt(x)∥2=0\partial_t \varphi_t(x) + \frac{1}{2}\|v_t(x)\|^2 = 0 ∂t​φt​(x)+21​∥vt​(x)∥2=0

To summarize, we have three equations for the action functional, which gives us the necessary conditions for optimality:

{vt=∇φt,Velocity field as gradient of potential∂tφt(x)+12∥vt(x)∥2=0,Hamilton-Jacobi equation∂tρt+∇⋅(vtρt)=0.Continuity equation for mass conservation\begin{cases} v_t = \nabla \varphi_t, \quad \text{Velocity field as gradient of potential} \\ \partial_t \varphi_t(x) + \frac{1}{2}\|v_t(x)\|^2 = 0, \quad \text{Hamilton-Jacobi equation} \\ \partial_t \rho_t + \nabla \cdot (v_t \rho_t) = 0. \quad \text{Continuity equation for mass conservation} \end{cases} ⎩⎨⎧​vt​=∇φt​,Velocity field as gradient of potential∂t​φt​(x)+21​∥vt​(x)∥2=0,Hamilton-Jacobi equation∂t​ρt​+∇⋅(vt​ρt​)=0.Continuity equation for mass conservation​

By the φ\varphiφ, we can get Kantorovich potential (ψ,ϕ)(\psi,\phi)(ψ,ϕ),

ψ(x):=φ1(x),ϕ(x)=−φ0(x)\psi(x):=\varphi_1(x), \quad \phi(x)=-\varphi_0(x) ψ(x):=φ1​(x),ϕ(x)=−φ0​(x)

as the dual potentials for the optimal transport problem.

One can prove it by integral along the optimal pair (x,T(x))(x,T(x))(x,T(x)), and verify the duality optimality. (Actually, this maybe give a proof to the Benamou-Brenier theorem)

Economic interpretation

The optimal transport problem can be interpreted in an economic context, where we want to transport resources (e.g., goods, people) from one location to another while minimizing the cost of transportation.

(Monge’s formulation)

min⁡∫Xc(x,T(x)) dμ(x)s.t.T∗μ=ν\begin{align*} \min \int_X c(x, T(x)) \, d\mu(x) \\ \text{s.t.} \quad T_* \mu = \nu \end{align*} min∫X​c(x,T(x))dμ(x)s.t.T∗​μ=ν​

where c(x,T(x))c(x, T(x))c(x,T(x)) is the cost of transporting from location xxx to location T(x)T(x)T(x), and μ\muμ and ν\nuν are the source and target distributions, respectively.

(Kantorovich’s formulation)

min⁡∫X×Yc(x,y) dγ(x,y)s.t.γ∈Π(μ,ν)\begin{align*} \min \int_{X \times Y} c(x, y) \, d\gamma(x, y) \\ \text{s.t.} \quad \gamma \in \Pi(\mu, \nu) \end{align*} min∫X×Y​c(x,y)dγ(x,y)s.t.γ∈Π(μ,ν)​

where γ\gammaγ is a joint distribution over the source and target locations, and Π(μ,ν)\Pi(\mu, \nu)Π(μ,ν) is the set of all couplings between μ\muμ and ν\nuν.

(Kantorovich dual formulation)

max⁡∫Xϕ(x) dμ(x)+∫Yψ(y) dν(y)s.t.ϕ(x)+ψ(y)≤c(x,y)∀(x,y)∈X×Y\begin{align*} \max \int_X \phi(x) \, d\mu(x) + \int_Y \psi(y) \, d\nu(y) \\ \text{s.t.} \quad \phi(x) + \psi(y) \leq c(x, y) \quad \forall (x, y) \in X \times Y \end{align*} max∫X​ϕ(x)dμ(x)+∫Y​ψ(y)dν(y)s.t.ϕ(x)+ψ(y)≤c(x,y)∀(x,y)∈X×Y​

Let’s consider the economic interpretation:

μ\muμ is the distribution of resources at the source location XXX, and ν\nuν is the target distribution of resources at the destination location YYY. The cost function c(x,y)c(x, y)c(x,y) represents the cost of transporting resources from location xxx to location yyy. And merchants are trying to maximize their profit by transporting resources.

Let φ(t,x)\varphi(t,x)φ(t,x) be the potential function that represents the value of resources at gt(x)∈Ωg_t(x)\in\Omegagt​(x)∈Ω, and in the nation XXX, let ϕ\phiϕ denote the cost of buying resources at xxx and ψ\psiψ denote the cost of selling resources at yyy.

Now look back at the setting:

ϕ:=−φ0,ψ:=φ1\phi:=-\varphi_0, \quad \psi:=\varphi_1 ϕ:=−φ0​,ψ:=φ1​

The potential ϕ\phiϕ represents the change of the balance of merchants buying resources at the source location XXX, and the potential ψ\psiψ represents the gain of merchants selling resources at the destination location YYY.

So the Kantorovich dual formulation can be interpreted as maximizing the profit of merchants by buying resources at the source location XXX and selling them at the destination location YYY.

And the no arbitrage condition ϕ(x)+ψ(y)≤c(x,y)\phi(x) + \psi(y) \leq c(x, y)ϕ(x)+ψ(y)≤c(x,y) ensures that the profit from buying and selling resources is not greater than the cost of transportation, preventing arbitrage opportunities.

Look back at the optimality conditions, we have:

  1. The velocity field vt=∇φtv_t = \nabla \varphi_tvt​=∇φt​ represents the optimal transportation direction of resources, which is the gradient of the potential function φt\varphi_tφt​.

This is quite intuitive.

  1. The Hamilton-Jacobi equation ∂tφt(x)+12∥vt(x)∥2=0\partial_t \varphi_t(x) + \frac{1}{2}\|v_t(x)\|^2 = 0∂t​φt​(x)+21​∥vt​(x)∥2=0 describes the evolution of the potential function over time, where the term 12∥vt(x)∥2\frac{1}{2}\|v_t(x)\|^221​∥vt​(x)∥2 can be interpreted as the cost of transportation.

But here is a problem, the cost of transportation is formulated as the integral of the instantaneous cost over time, but in the original optimal transport problem, the cost is formulated as independent of path, i.e., the cost is only dependent on the source and target locations, not on the path taken.

To make the two formulations consistent, we impose a constraint:

Let

C[γ]=∫01c(γ˙t) dtC[\gamma]=\int_0^1 c(\dot\gamma_t)\, dt C[γ]=∫01​c(γ˙​t​)dt

be the cost of transportation along the path γ\gammaγ, if

c(x,y)=inf⁡{C[(γt)t∈[0,1]]}for all (x,y)∈X×Yc(x,y) = \inf\left\{C[(\gamma_t)_{t\in[0,1]}]\right\} \quad \text{for all } (x,y)\in X\times Y c(x,y)=inf{C[(γt​)t∈[0,1]​]}for all (x,y)∈X×Y

then the two formulations give the same optimal transport plan.

A common situation is

c(x,y):=c(y−x)=∥x−y∥kc(x,y):= c(y-x) = \|x-y\|^k c(x,y):=c(y−x)=∥x−y∥k

where k≥1k\geq 1k≥1 is an integer.

When k=1k=1k=1, the cost function is linear and not strictly convex, and the optimal transport plan is not unique. Any linear parameterization of the line segment connecting xxx and yyy will yield the same cost.

When k≥2k\geq 2k≥2, the cost function is strictly convex, and the optimal transport plan is unique. The optimal path is the straight line connecting xxx and yyy with velocity parameterized by the arc length.

Lemma: If ccc is a convex function over Rn\mathbb R^nRn, then

inf⁡{∫01c(γ˙t)dt;γ0=x,γ1=y}=c(y−x)\inf\left\{\int_0^1 c(\dot\gamma_t) dt; \gamma_0=x,\gamma_1=y\right\} = c(y-x) inf{∫01​c(γ˙​t​)dt;γ0​=x,γ1​=y}=c(y−x)

Moreover, if ccc is strictly convex, then the infimum is achieved by a unique path γt=tx+(1−t)y\gamma_t = tx + (1-t)yγt​=tx+(1−t)y.

Proof

Use the Jensen’s inequality of integral.

So for the 222-Wasserstein distance, the cost function can be seen as the integral of velocity field over time.

c(x,y)=inf⁡Cpath=∫01c(γ˙t)dt=∫01vt(x)dt=12∥y−x∥22c(x,y)=\inf C_{\text{path}}=\int_0^1 c(\dot\gamma_t) dt = \int_0^1 v_t(x) dt = \frac{1}{2}\|y-x\|_2^2 c(x,y)=infCpath​=∫01​c(γ˙​t​)dt=∫01​vt​(x)dt=21​∥y−x∥22​

where the best path γt\gamma_tγt​ is the straight line connecting xxx and yyy with constant velocity γ˙t=1\dot\gamma_t=1γ˙​t​=1.

Why Conditioning Works?

Turning back to the rectified flow, the author condition on x0,x1x_0,x_1x0​,x1​, let π(x0,x1)\pi(x_0,x_1)π(x0​,x1​) be the product coupling μ(x0)ν(x1)\mu(x_0)\nu(x_1)μ(x0​)ν(x1​).

vt(xt∣x0,x1)=x1−x0vt(xt)=∫∫vt(xt∣x0,x1)ρt(xt∣x0,x1)π(x0,x1)ρt(xt) dx0 dx1=∫∫(x1−x0)ρt(xt∣x0,x1)μ(x0)ν(x1)ρt(xt) dx0 dx1\begin{align*} v_t(x_t|x_0,x_1) &= x_1-x_0\\ v_t(x_t) &= \int \int v_t(x_t|x_0,x_1) \frac{\rho_t(x_t|x_0,x_1)\pi(x_0,x_1)}{\rho_t(x_t)} \, dx_0 \, dx_1\\ &= \int \int (x_1-x_0) \frac{\rho_t(x_t|x_0,x_1)\mu(x_0)\nu(x_1)}{\rho_t(x_t)} \, dx_0 \, dx_1\\ \end{align*} vt​(xt​∣x0​,x1​)vt​(xt​)​=x1​−x0​=∫∫vt​(xt​∣x0​,x1​)ρt​(xt​)ρt​(xt​∣x0​,x1​)π(x0​,x1​)​dx0​dx1​=∫∫(x1​−x0​)ρt​(xt​)ρt​(xt​∣x0​,x1​)μ(x0​)ν(x1​)​dx0​dx1​​

It is easy to see if π=π∗\pi = \pi^*π=π∗, then the marginal vector field vt(xt)v_t(x_t)vt​(xt​) is exactly the optimal transport vector field.

But rectified flow set π=μ⊗ν\pi = \mu \otimes \nuπ=μ⊗ν, so it cannot get the optimal transport vector field in 1 step. But the paper proves every time of reflow matching will decrease the transport cost, and the rectified flow will converge to the optimal transport vector field by the speed of O(1/k)\mathcal{O}(1/k)O(1/k),
where kkk is the number of iterations.

And in the Flow Matching For Generative Modeling, the author proposed “OT-flow” is conditioning on x1x_1x1​ only. Therefore, since the target is a Gaussian kernal and the source is a Gaussian distribution, they just know the exact form of the optimal transport vector field

vt(xt∣x1)=x1−(1−σmin)xt1−(1−σmin)tv_t(x_t|x_1) = \frac{x_1 - (1-\sigma_{min})x_t}{1-(1-\sigma_{min})t} vt​(xt​∣x1​)=1−(1−σmin​)tx1​−(1−σmin​)xt​​

and there is no problem of coupling since they only condition on x1x_1x1​.

Why Reflow Works?

The 111-rectified flow is calculated by:

vt1(x)=E(x0,x1)∼π0[x1−x0∣x=tx0+(1−t)x1]\begin{align*} v_t^1(x) = \mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi_0} \left[x_1-x_0 | x = t x_0 + (1-t) x_1\right] \end{align*} vt1​(x)=E(x0​,x1​)∼π0​​[x1​−x0​∣x=tx0​+(1−t)x1​]​

where π0=μ⊗ν\pi_0 = \mu \otimes \nuπ0​=μ⊗ν is the independent coupling of the source and target distributions.
This is the expectation of line direction that pass xxx at time ttt.

For k≥2k\geq 2k≥2, the kkk-rectified flow is calculated by:

vtk(x)=E(x0,x1)∼πk−1[x1−x0∣x=tx0+(1−t)x1]\begin{align*} v_t^k(x) = \mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi_{k-1}} \left[x_1-x_0 | x = t x_0 + (1-t) x_1\right] \end{align*} vtk​(x)=E(x0​,x1​)∼πk−1​​[x1​−x0​∣x=tx0​+(1−t)x1​]​

where πk−1=πg1k−1=(Id,g1k−1)∗μ\pi_{k-1} =\pi_{g^{k-1}_1} = (\text{Id}, g_1^{k-1})_* \muπk−1​=πg1k−1​​=(Id,g1k−1​)∗​μ is the coupling induced by the (k−1)(k-1)(k−1)-rectified flow.

C(π)=E(x0,x1)∼π[c(x0,x1)]C(\pi)=\mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi} \left[c(x_0,x_1)\right] C(π)=E(x0​,x1​)∼π​[c(x0​,x1​)]

as the transport cost of the coupling π\piπ.

We assume the cost function has the form c(x,y)=c(y−x)c(x,y)=c(y-x)c(x,y)=c(y−x) and ccc is convex and C1C^1C1, we know the cost can be represented as the infimum of the path cost.

We has the following transform sequence:

π0=μ⊗ν→Φg1→Ψπ1→Φg2→Ψ⋯→Φgk→Ψπk\pi_0=\mu \otimes \nu \xrightarrow{\Phi} g^1 \xrightarrow{\Psi} \pi_1 \xrightarrow{\Phi} g^2 \xrightarrow{\Psi} \cdots \xrightarrow{\Phi} g^{k} \xrightarrow{\Psi} \pi_{k} π0​=μ⊗νΦ​g1Ψ​π1​Φ​g2Ψ​⋯Φ​gkΨ​πk​

where Ψ\PsiΨ is pushforward Ψ(g)=(Id,g)∗μ\Psi(g)=(\text{Id}, g)_*\muΨ(g)=(Id,g)∗​μ.

For Φ\PhiΦ, given π\piπ, vvv is calculated by:

vt(x)=E(x0,x1)∼π[x1−x0∣x=tx0+(1−t)x1]v_t(x) = \mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi} \left[x_1-x_0 | x = t x_0 + (1-t) x_1\right] vt​(x)=E(x0​,x1​)∼π​[x1​−x0​∣x=tx0​+(1−t)x1​]

And ggg is determined by the following equation:

{ddtgt(x)=vt(gt(x))g0(x)=x.\begin{cases} \frac{d}{dt}g_t(x) = v_t(g_t(x)) \\ g_0(x)=x. \end{cases} {dtd​gt​(x)=vt​(gt​(x))g0​(x)=x.​

Theorem:

C(πk+1)≤C(πk) for all k≥1C(\pi_{k+1}) \leq C(\pi_k)\, \text{for all } k\geq 1 C(πk+1​)≤C(πk​)for all k≥1

Proof:

C(πk+1)=E(x0,x1)∼πk+1[c(x1−x0)]=E(x0,x1)∼πk+1[c(∫01vtk+1(gtk+1(x0)))dt]≤E(x0,x1)∼πk+1[∫01c(vtk+1(gtk+1(x0)))dt](by Jensen’s inequality)=∫01E(x0,x1)∼πk+1[c(vtk+1(gtk+1(x0)))]dt=∫01Ext∼ρtk+1[c(vtk+1(xt))]dt=∫01Ext∼ρtk[c(vtk+1(xt))]dt=E(x0,x1)∼πk[∫01c(vtk+1(xt))dt]=E(x0,x1)∼πk[∫01c(E[x1−x0∣xt])dt]≤E(x0,x1)∼πk[∫01E[c(x1−x0)∣xt]dt](Jensen)=E(x0,x1)∼πk[c(x1−x0)]=C(πk)\begin{align*} C(\pi_{k+1}) &= \mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi_{k+1}} \left[c(x_1-x_0)\right]\\ &=\mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi_{k+1}} \left[c \left(\int_0^1 v_t^{k+1}(g_t^{k+1}(x_0))\right) dt\right] \\ &\leq \mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi_{k+1}} \left[\int_0^1 c\left(v_t^{k+1}(g_t^{k+1}(x_0))\right) dt\right] \quad \text{(by Jensen's inequality)}\\ &= \int_0^1 \mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi_{k+1}} \left[c\left(v_t^{k+1}(g_t^{k+1}(x_0))\right)\right] dt\\ &= \int_0^1 \mathbb{E}_{x_t \sim \rho_t^{k+1}} \left[c\left(v_t^{k+1}(x_t)\right)\right] dt\\ &= \int_0^1 \mathbb{E}_{x_t \sim \rho_t^k} \left[c\left(v_t^{k+1}(x_t)\right)\right] dt\\ &= \mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi_k} \left[\int_0^1 c\left(v_t^{k+1}(x_t)\right) dt\right]\\ &= \mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi_k} \left[\int_0^1 c\left(\mathbb{E}[x_1-x_0|x_t] \right) dt\right]\\ &\leq \mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi_k} \left[\int_0^1 \mathbb{E}[c(x_1-x_0)|x_t] dt\right] \quad \text{(Jensen)}\\ &= \mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi_k} \left[c(x_1-x_0)\right] \\ &= C(\pi_k) \end{align*} C(πk+1​)​=E(x0​,x1​)∼πk+1​​[c(x1​−x0​)]=E(x0​,x1​)∼πk+1​​[c(∫01​vtk+1​(gtk+1​(x0​)))dt]≤E(x0​,x1​)∼πk+1​​[∫01​c(vtk+1​(gtk+1​(x0​)))dt](by Jensen’s inequality)=∫01​E(x0​,x1​)∼πk+1​​[c(vtk+1​(gtk+1​(x0​)))]dt=∫01​Ext​∼ρtk+1​​[c(vtk+1​(xt​))]dt=∫01​Ext​∼ρtk​​[c(vtk+1​(xt​))]dt=E(x0​,x1​)∼πk​​[∫01​c(vtk+1​(xt​))dt]=E(x0​,x1​)∼πk​​[∫01​c(E[x1​−x0​∣xt​])dt]≤E(x0​,x1​)∼πk​​[∫01​E[c(x1​−x0​)∣xt​]dt](Jensen)=E(x0​,x1​)∼πk​​[c(x1​−x0​)]=C(πk​)​

Note that ρt\rho_tρt​ as the marginal distribution of xt=tx1+(1−t)x0x_t = t x_1 + (1-t)x_0xt​=tx1​+(1−t)x0​, ρt′\rho_{t}'ρt′​ is the distribution generated by the marginal vector field vtk+1v_t^{k+1}vtk+1​. They are the same since the continuity equation is satisfied.

Proof

For all ϕ∈C0(Ω)\phi\in C_0(\Omega)ϕ∈C0​(Ω),

ddtE(x0,x1)∼πk[ϕ(xt)]=E(x0,x1)∼πk[∇ϕ(xt)⋅(x1−x0)]=Ex∼ρtk[∇ϕ(x)E(x0,x1)∼πk[x1−x0∣xt=x]]=Ex∼ρtk[∇ϕ(x)⋅vtk+1(x)]\begin{align*} \frac{d}{dt} \mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi^k}[\phi(x_t)] &= \mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi^k} \left[\nabla \phi(x_t) \cdot (x_1 - x_0)\right] \\ &=\mathbb{E}_{x\sim \rho_t^k} \left[\nabla \phi(x) \mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi^k}[x_1 - x_0 | x_t = x]\right] \\ &=\mathbb{E}_{x\sim \rho_t^k} \left[\nabla \phi(x) \cdot v_t^{k+1}(x)\right] \end{align*} dtd​E(x0​,x1​)∼πk​[ϕ(xt​)]​=E(x0​,x1​)∼πk​[∇ϕ(xt​)⋅(x1​−x0​)]=Ex∼ρtk​​[∇ϕ(x)E(x0​,x1​)∼πk​[x1​−x0​∣xt​=x]]=Ex∼ρtk​​[∇ϕ(x)⋅vtk+1​(x)]​

Solves the weak form of the continuity equation.

This is the key construct in the rectified flow.

Straightness

Define

S(g)=∫01E(x0,x1)∼πg1[∥x1−x0−vt(xt)∥2]dtS(g)=\int_0^1 \mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi_{g_1}} \left[\|x_1-x_0-v_t(x_t)\|^2\right] dt S(g)=∫01​E(x0​,x1​)∼πg1​​​[∥x1​−x0​−vt​(xt​)∥2]dt

as the straightness of the flow ggg.

Theorem 3.7 in Flow Straight and Fast states:

min⁡k∈{1,⋯ ,K}S(Zk)≤E(x0,x1)∼π0[∥x1−x0∥2]K\min_{k\in\{1,\cdots,K\}} S(Z^k) \leq \frac{\mathbb{E}_{(x_0,x_1)\sim \pi_0}[\|x_1-x_0\|^2]}{K} k∈{1,⋯,K}min​S(Zk)≤KE(x0​,x1​)∼π0​​[∥x1​−x0​∥2]​
